      static double haversine(java.lang.String lat1s, java.lang.String lon1s, java.lang.String lat2s, java.lang.String lon2s)
      convert it to bigdecimal form source:http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Haversine_formula#Java ? Not converting to BigDecimal for performance concerns, This uses the ‘haversine’ formula to calculate the great-circle distance between two points – that is, the shortest distance over the earth’s surface – giving an ‘as-the-crow-flies’ distance between the points (ignoring any hills they fly over, of course!).
      TODO LATER can use non-native math libraries for faster computation.

      • haversine

        public static double haversine(java.lang.String lat1s,
                               java.lang.String lon1s,
                               java.lang.String lat2s,
                               java.lang.String lon2s)
        convert it to bigdecimal form source:http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Haversine_formula#Java ? Not converting to BigDecimal for performance concerns, This uses the ‘haversine’ formula to calculate the great-circle distance between two points – that is, the shortest distance over the earth’s surface – giving an ‘as-the-crow-flies’ distance between the points (ignoring any hills they fly over, of course!).
        TODO LATER can use non-native math libraries for faster computation. User jafama or apache common maths.
        Parameters:
        lat1 -
        lon1 -
        lat2 -
        lon2 -
        Returns:
        distance in Kilometers

        Fork of haversine() to improve speed

        convert it to bigdecimal form source:http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Haversine_formula#Java ? Not converting to BigDecimal for performance concerns, This uses the ‘haversine’ formula to calculate the great-circle distance between two points – that is, the shortest distance over the earth’s surface – giving an ‘as-the-crow-flies’ distance between the points (ignoring any hills they fly over, of course!).

                                       java.lang.String lon1s,
                                       java.lang.String lat2s,

        This uses the ‘haversine’ formula to calculate the great-circle distance between two points – that is, the shortest distance over the earth’s surface – giving an ‘as-the-crow-flies’ distance between the points (ignoring any hills they fly over, of course!).
        uses FastMath from apache common maths as drop in replacement for java's standard Math.
